data:
This instructional manual was designed to aid artists in drawing human figures.

Albrecht Dürer (1471–1528), author; Louis Meigret (ca. 1500–after 1558), translator 
Les Qvatre livres d’Albert Dvrer, peinctre & geometrien tres excellent, de la proportion des parties & pourtraicts des corps humains (The four books of Albrecht Dürer, the most excellent painter and geometrician, on the proportion of the different parts and portraits of the human body) 
Paris: Charles Perier, 1557
John M. Wing Collection

Albrecht Dürer intended the Four Books on Human Proportion to help artists draw parts of the body, including the head. The text defines several ideal types of human physiognomy that are described in classical sources. “Physiognomy” refers to facial and cranial measurements that were alleged to be indicative of personal character as well as ethnic origin. Dürer’s text goes on to explain how artists can apply mathematical projections to alter these types and generate varied, imagined, human forms like the profiles shown here. 

Albrecht Dürer (1471–1528), author; Louis Meigret (ca. 1500–after 1558), translator 
Les Qvatre livres d’Albert Dvrer, peinctre & geometrien tres excellent, de la proportion des parties & pourtraicts des corps humains (The four books of Albrecht Dürer, the most excellent painter and geometrician, on the proportion of the different parts and portraits of the human body) 
Paris: Charles Perier, 1557
John M. Wing Collection

This profile of a Black African with curly hair, drawn from life, is compared to an “ideal” white European profile. In other parts of his text, Dürer claims that African faces, and especially noses, are less handsome than European faces. Later artists followed Dürer’s ideas when constructing ideal representations of white European people. This mode of comparison is a precursor of racial profiling today.  


Albrecht Dürer (1471–1528), author; Louis Meigret (ca. 1500–after 1558), translator 
Les Qvatre livres d’Albert Dvrer, peinctre & geometrien tres excellent, de la proportion des parties & pourtraicts des corps humains (The four books of Albrecht Dürer, the most excellent painter and geometrician, on the proportion of the different parts and portraits of the human body) 
Paris: Charles Perier, 1557
John M. Wing Collection

Dürer’s ideas about portraying race were very popular. First published in German in 1528, this work was translated into five languages, and issued in more than 15 editions over more than 125 years, including the French, Italian, and German editions in the Newberry collections. The stains splashed on the right page of this edition suggest how frequently these editions were used.
